artist: Artist: Utagawa Hiroshige; Publisher: Sakanaya Eikichi
catalogue_raissonne: Ukiyo-e shūka 14 (1981), Hiroshige list, p. 250, vertical ōban #62.72
creditline: Gift of Louis W. Hill, Jr.
medium: Woodblock print (nishiki-e); ink and color on paper
portfolio: From One Hundred Famous Views of Edo (Meisho Edo hyakkei 名所江戸百景)
text: Tsukudajima is a manmade island at the mouth of the Sumida River. Fishermen who settled there from western Japan constructed a shrine dedicated to Sumiyoshi, the god of the sea. This print depicts the highlight of a festival held at the shrine every summer. The white banner in the center is emblazoned with the name of the Sumiyoshi god. Behind the banner, held by a number of naked men is a mikoshi, a portable shrine for transporting the spirit of the god. It is about to be placed in a boat and carried out to sea, symbolizing the god's return to his watery home.
title: Sumiyoshi Festival, Tsukudajima
